[[Mentioned in Despatches]] |laterwork= }} [[Air Vice Marshal (Australia)|Air Vice Marshal]] '''Allan Leslie Walters''', [[Order of the Bath|CB]], [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]], [[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|AFC]] (2 November 1905 – 19 October 1968) was a senior commander in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF). Born in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] and raised in [[Western Australia]], he graduated from the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]], before transferring to the RAAF in 1928. He was considered one of the service's leading [[Flight instructor|flying instructors]] and [[aerobatics|aerobatic]] pilots between the wars, and was appointed to his first [[Squadron (aviation)|squadron]] command in 1937. Over the course of [[Military history of Australia during World War II|World War II]], Walters led [[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 (General Reconnaissance) Squadron]] in [[Singapore]], [[No. 1 Wing RAAF|No. 1 (Fighter) Wing]] in [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], Northern Territory, [[No. 72 Wing RAAF|No. 72 Wing]] in [[Netherlands New Guinea|Dutch New Guinea]], and [[Northern Command (RAAF)|Northern Command]] in [[Papua New Guinea]]. He was decorated with the [[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|Air Force Cross]] in 1941 for his work with No. 1 Squadron, and [[mentioned in despatches]] in 1944 for his service with No. 72 Wing. Walters was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in 1946 for his service with Northern Command. Already marked out for senior roles in the post-war RAAF, his positions during the 1950s included [[Air Officer Commanding]] (AOC) [[Southern Area Command (RAAF)|Southern Area Command]], AOC [[RAAF Overseas Headquarters]] in London, Head of the Australian Joint Services Staff in Washington, D.C., AOC [[RAAF Air Command|Home Command]], [[Air Member for Personnel (Australia)|Air Member for Personnel]], and AOC [[RAAF Support Command|Support Command]]. He was promoted acting [[air vice marshal]] in 1952 ([[Military rank#Types of rank|substantive]] in 1954), and appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in 1956. Popularly known as "Wally",{{cite web|last=Funnell|first=Ray|authorlink=Ray Funnell|url=http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A160574b.htm|title=Walters, Allan Leslie (1905–1968)|work= [[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]|accessdate= 12 May 2013}} he was twice a candidate for [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]], and twice passed over. He retired from the RAAF in 1962 and made his home in [[Melbourne]], where he died in 1968 at the age of sixty-two. ==Early career== Allan Leslie Walters was born on 2 November 1905 in [[Ascot Vale, Victoria|Ascot Vale]], Victoria, to schoolteacher Ferdinand Walters and his wife Edith. The family soon moved to [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], Western Australia, and Allan completed his education at Perth Modern School, where he joined the [[Australian Army Cadets|cadets]]. After leaving school and spending eight months in the [[Australian Army Reserve|militia]], he entered the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]], in February 1924. At Duntroon he specialised in [[field artillery]], and excelled at athletics.{{cite news|title=34 years service ends|work=RAAF News|date=May 1962|page= 6}} Graduating as a [[lieutenant]] in December 1927, he transferred to the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) on 1 February 1928.{{cite web|url=http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?ServiceId=R&VeteranId=1081091|title=Walters, Allan Leslie|work= World War 2 Nominal Roll|accessdate=12 March 2010}} Walters' preferred career path in the military was engineering, and it was only when he failed to gain selection for this field after his graduation that he applied to transfer to the Air Force, which, having no cadet college of its own, had arranged with Duntroon to take one of its artillery specialists each year for [[Wiktionary:secondment|secondment]] as a pilot.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 191–192, 196 He commenced his course at [[RAAF Williams|RAAF Point Cook]], Victoria, in mid-1928, and graduated as a [[flying officer]] in March 1929. Walters showed an aptitude for instruction, and after further training was graded an 'A1' [[flight instructor]], a rare distinction. Posted to [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]] at [[RAAF Base Richmond|RAAF Station Richmond]], New South Wales, operating [[Westland Wapiti]]s, he also made a name for himself performing [[aerobatics]] at air shows throughout the country.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 31–33 Walters put this particular talent to use in pursuit of his wife-to-be, Jean Manning, stunt flying above All Saints Church, [[North Parramatta, New South Wales|North Parramatta]], where her father was [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]]. Reverend Manning married the couple there on 30 June 1930; their daughter Robin was born in Richmond.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article12637533 |title=Two service wives and a daughter |newspaper=[[The Sun-Herald]] |location=Sydney |date=31 January 1954 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=36 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} [[File:P00448.195RichmondWapitis.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Westland Wapitis of No. 3 Squadron in the Richmond area, October 1932|alt=Overhead view of three single-engined biplanes in flight]] Walters was granted a permanent commission in the Air Force in 1930. On 5 January 1931, by now promoted [[flight lieutenant]], he won a trophy in an air obstacle race at the [[Cootamundra]] Air Pageant. In May the following year, he took out the NSW Air Derby and Evening News Cup.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 38–39 He temporarily commanded No. 3 Squadron during October 1933, in the absence of Squadron Leader [[William Bostock|Bill Bostock]]. At the time, the commanding officer of No. 3 Squadron also held command of RAAF Station Richmond.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 46, 123 Walters was posted to Britain in 1936 to attend the [[Royal Air Force Staff College, Andover]], and was promoted to [[squadron leader]] in March 1937, while still overseas.Coulthard-Clark, ''Air Marshals of the RAAF'', p. 34 He also undertook a naval reconnaissance course at [[RAF Manston]]. Returning to Australia in May, he took command of [[No. 22 Squadron RAAF|No. 22 Squadron]] in June, flying [[Hawker Demon]]s and [[Avro Anson]]s out of Richmond until February 1938.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', p. 115 Between 6 and 23 February 1938, Walters piloted the first overseas flight in an aeroplane designed and built in Australia when he flew the [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Vice Marshal [[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Richard Williams]], to [[Singapore]] in a [[Tugan Gannet]].Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 394 He returned to Richmond in May 1938 to lead No. 3 Squadron, operating Demons, and again took part in aerobatic displays.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article103212329 |title=Thousands flock to Narromine air pageant |newspaper=Narromine News and Trangie Advocate |location=Narromine, New South Wales |date=27 September 1938 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=4 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}} On 25 October 1938, his Demon crashed in scrub at [[Tumbi Umbi, New South Wales|Tumbi Umbi]], New South Wales, when the engine failed shortly after taking off for Richmond, but he was not injured.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article94602887 |title=Hawker Demon crashed into scrub |newspaper=[[The Northern Star]] |location=Lismore, New South Wales |date=26 October 1938 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Completing his Richmond appointment in May 1939, Walters transferred to [[Melbourne]] as Director of Staff Duties at RAAF Headquarters. Later that month, he joined Group Captain [[Henry Wrigley]] as an expert assessor on the panel of an inquiry into a recent series of three Anson accidents; the full report handed down in October found human error the likely explanation for at least one crash and that training on the type followed the syllabus laid down, but that pilots needed more practical experience in dealing with potential in-flight incidents.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 349–350 ==World War II== [[File:AWM012244JonesHancockHewitt.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Group Captain Walters (second from left) in May 1942 with members of HQ Allied Air Forces SWPA, including Group Captain [[Valston Hancock|Val Hancock]] (centre), Air Commodore [[Joe Hewitt (RAAF officer)|Joe Hewitt]] (second from right), and newly appointed Chief of the Air Staff, Air Vice Marshal [[George Jones (RAAF officer)|George Jones]] (right, seated)|alt=Five men, four standing and one seated, wearing dark-coloured military uniforms]] Walters' first operational appointment following the outbreak of [[Military history of Australia during World War II|World War II]] was as commanding officer of [[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 (General Reconnaissance) Squadron]], which he led to [[Sembawang]], Singapore, in July 1940.Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/07.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 141–142] His promotion to temporary [[Wing Commander (rank)|wing commander]] was announced the same month.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article25814086 |title= Promotion received |newspaper=[[The Mercury (Hobart)|The Mercury]] |location=Hobart |date=17 July 1940 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} He had earlier travelled incognito to Singapore on a [[Qantas]] [[Short Empire|Empire flying boat]], which had been specifically requested to deviate from its normal flight path so that he could reconnoiter airfields in the [[Dutch East Indies]].Helson, ''The Forgotten Air Force'', pp. 54–55 Deployed in response to fears of [[Empire of Japan|Japanese]] expansion in [[Malaysia|Malaya]], No. 1 Squadron was the first Australian unit equipped with [[Lockheed Hudson]] light bombers, which were employed primarily for [[maritime patrol]] work.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_11019second_world_war.asp|title=No. 1 Squadron|publisher =[[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate=12 March 2010}} Walters was awarded the [[Air Force Cross (United Kingdom)|Air Force Cross]] for his "very active part in all operations" and for training his unit to "a particularly high standard"; the honour was [[London Gazette|gazetted]] in the 1941 [[King's Birthday Honours]].{{LondonGazette|issue=35204|supp=yes|startpage=3752|date=1 July 1941|accessdate=on 12 March 2010}} He succeeded [[Frank Lukis]] as commanding officer of [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Laverton Base|RAAF Station Laverton]], Victoria, in May the same year, and was promoted acting [[group captain]].RAAF Historical Section, ''Introduction, Bases, Supporting Organisations'', pp. 144–145 In May 1942, he joined Allied Air Forces Headquarters, [[South West Pacific Area (command)|South West Pacific Area]] (SWPA), in Melbourne as Assistant Director of Operations.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force!'', p. 112 He was made a temporary group captain in September, and transferred to Headquarters [[RAAF Command]] as senior air staff officer.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2602686 |title=RAAF promotions|newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |location=Canberra |date=25 September 1942 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/28.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 588] On 7 October 1942, Walters took command of a new formation, [[No. 1 Wing RAAF|No. 1 (Fighter) Wing]], at RAAF Station Richmond. Established to boost the air defence capability of Australia's [[North-Western Area Command (RAAF)|North-Western Area]], the wing comprised three [[Supermarine Spitfire]] squadrons that had been transferred from Europe: [[No. 54 Squadron RAF|No. 54 Squadron RAF]], [[No. 452 Squadron RAAF|No. 452 Squadron RAAF]] and [[No. 457 Squadron RAAF|No. 457 Squadron RAAF]]. With Wing Commander [[Clive Caldwell]], Australia's top-scoring [[flying ace]] of the war, as his wing leader, Walters began deploying aircraft and men to [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], Northern Territory, in December, providing a filip for morale in the region.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 83–84Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/30.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 651–652] Proudly declaring himself Australia's oldest fighter pilot, Walters was reported as taking every opportunity to join his men in the air.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17857219 |title=Fighter pilot at 37 |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=Sydney |date=22 July 1943 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} He flew as Caldwell's [[wingman]] in No. 1 Wing's [[Raid on Darwin (2 May 1943)|first major action]] against the Japanese over Darwin on 2 May 1943.Alexander, ''Clive Caldwell'', pp. 109–111 Eight Spitfires crashed and several others made forced landings, for the destruction of one Japanese bomber and five fighters.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/03.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 46–49] Walters himself narrowly avoiding being shot down when he warned Caldwell of an attacking enemy fighter, to the detriment of his own safety. After they landed, Caldwell chided his commander, "You silly old so-and-so. You want to look after your own skin instead of worrying about someone else's!" On 20 June, Walters participated in the wing's most successful combat against the Japanese to that time, personally accounting for one of fourteen raiders claimed by the Spitfires, for the loss of two of their own number.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/04.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 59–60] He posted out of Darwin a few days later, having earned the admiration of Caldwell and the rest of the wing's personnel.Alexander, ''Clive Caldwell'', p. 141 [[File:OG0540Walters72Wing1943.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Walters (right) as Officer Commanding No. 72 Wing in New Guinea, December 1943|alt=Three men in light-coloured uniforms with peaked caps seated on a jeep bonnet]] Walters assumed command of [[No. 5 Service Flying Training School RAAF|No. 5 Service Flying Training School]] in [[Uranquinty]], New South Wales, on 30 June 1943, but the next month was posted to [[Merauke]] in Dutch New Guinea to take over [[No. 72 Wing RAAF|No. 72 Wing]] following reassignment of its original commander, Group Captain [[Charles Eaton (RAAF officer)|Charles Eaton]].{{cite web|last=Clark|first=Chris|url=http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A140082b.htm|title= Eaton, Charles (1895–1979)|work= Australian Dictionary of Biography|accessdate= 12 May 2013}}RAAF Historical Section, ''Training Units'', p. 108 Comprising [[No. 84 Squadron RAAF|No. 84 Squadron]] (flying [[CAC Boomerang]] fighters), [[No. 86 Squadron RAAF|No. 86 Squadron]] ([[Curtiss P-40 variants|Curtiss P-40 Kittyhawk]] fighters), and [[No. 12 Squadron RAAF|No. 12 Squadron]] ([[Vultee A-31 Vengeance]] dive bombers), No. 72 Wing came under the control of RAAF [[North-Eastern Area Command (RAAF)|North-Eastern Area Command]], and undertook air defence and patrol tasks in and around western New Guinea.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/07.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 114–116] Group Captain [[William Hely|Bill Hely]] assumed command of No. 72 Wing in May 1944, and Walters was appointed Director of Staff Policy and Plans at RAAF Headquarters.{{cite web|last=Eaton|first=Brian|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/hely-william-lloyd-bill-10480/text18591|title=Hely, William Lloyd (Bill) (1909–1970)|work= Australian Dictionary of Biography|accessdate= 12 May 2013}} He was [[mentioned in despatches]] on 28 October 1944 for his "Gallant & distinguished service" in North-Eastern Area, the award being promulgated on 9 March 1945.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM192/00302/003020402.pdf|title= Recommendation: Mention in Dispatches|publisher= Australian War Memorial|accessdate= 12 March 2010}}{{LondonGazette|issue=36975|supp=yes|startpage=1326|date=9 March 1945|accessdate=on 12 March 2010}} In February 1945, Walters was promoted to acting [[air commodore]] and took over from Air Commodore Lukis as [[Air Officer Commanding]] (AOC) [[Northern Command (RAAF)|Northern Command]], directing its operations in New Guinea, [[New Britain]] and [[Bougainville Island|Bougainville]] until the end of the war.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force!'', pp. 295 Headquartered at [[Madang]] in Papua New Guinea, Northern Command had previously been a large mobile formation known as [[No. 9 Operational Group RAAF|No. 9 (Operational) Group]] but had evolved into a garrison force, its mobile function supplanted by No. 10 (Operational) Group (later [[Australian First Tactical Air Force|First Tactical Air Force]]).Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/20.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 335]Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 144, 168 Northern Command's operational formations included [[No. 71 Wing RAAF|No. 71 Wing]] in northern New Guinea, [[No. 74 Wing RAAF|No. 74 Wing]] at [[Port Moresby]], and [[No. 84 Wing RAAF|No. 84 Wing]] on Bougainville.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27575769 |title=Governor will lead march |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney |date=22 April 1950 |accessdate=26 May 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} No. 71 Wing, commanded by Group Captain [[Valston Hancock|Val Hancock]], supported the [[6th Division (Australia)|Australian 6th Division]] during the [[Aitape–Wewak Campaign]], despite ordnance deficiencies that at one stage led to its squadrons arming their [[Bristol Beaufort]]s with captured Japanese bombs.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/20.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 335, 343–347] No. 84 Wing suffered shortages in pilots and equipment during the [[Bougainville Campaign]], and morale problems following the end of the war owing to inactivity and the uncertainties of demobilisation; as a result, the wing's commanding officer sent Northern Command headquarters a frank report, the tone of which earned a rebuke from Walters.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/19.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', p. 326]{{cite web|author=No. 84 (Army Co-operation) Wing|title=Operations record book |url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=1753386| pages=21–23|accessdate=26 May 2013}} In September, Walters represented the RAAF at the Japanese surrender ceremonies in [[Wewak]]. ==Post-war career== Walters was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the King's Birthday Honours on 25 June 1946, for his "conspicuous service in operations against the Japanese" while leading Northern Command during the war.{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/AWM192/00302/003020400.pdf|title= Recommendation: Commander of the Order of the British Empire|publisher= Australian War Memorial|accessdate=12 March 2010}}{{LondonGazette|issue=37625|supp=yes|startpage=3217|date=25 June 1946|accessdate=on 12 March 2010}} After completing his term as AOC Northern Command that year, Walters again became Director of Staff Plans and Policy at RAAF Headquarters. He attended the [[Royal College of Defence Studies|Imperial Defence College, London]], in 1947. Walters was among a small coterie of highly regarded operational commanders, including Air Commodores [[John McCauley (RAAF officer)|John McCauley]], [[Frederick Scherger|Fred Scherger]] and Val Hancock, earmarked by the Australian Air Board for senior leadership roles in the post-war RAAF.Helson, ''Ten Years at the Top'', p. 238Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 24–27, 73 In the short term, he remained a temporary air commodore—with the [[Military rank#Types of rank|substantive rank]] of group captain from May 1947—as the officer corps shrank drastically with demobilisation.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article27900305 |title=Promotions in RAAF |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney |date=30 May 1947 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} He was selected as AOC [[Southern Area Command (RAAF)|Southern Area Command]], hub of the RAAF's training organisation, in March 1948.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article22545750 |title=New AOC chosen for Southern Command |newspaper=[[The Argus (Australia)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=25 March 1948 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 73–75 The following month, he flew to [[Morotai]] to preside over a [[court-martial]] for an RAAF airman accused of killing an officer of the Dutch merchant marine; the airman was acquitted.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article80796006 |title=Court to try airman |newspaper=[[Daily News (Perth, Western Australia)|The Daily News]] |location=Perth |date=7 April 1948 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=7 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59648726 |title=RAAF court martial |newspaper=Centralian Advocate |location=Alice Springs, Northern Territory |date=16 April 1948 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} [[File:AllanWalters1954a.jpg|thumb|Air Vice Marshal Walters as Air Officer Commanding Home Command, 1954|alt=Head-and-shoulders portrait of a caucasian man in light-coloured uniform with peaked cap and pilot's wings on left-breast pocket]] In January 1951, Walters was appointed AOC [[RAAF Overseas Headquarters]] in London.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18197041 |title=RAAF command appointments |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney|date=31 January 1951 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} That December, he was part of the Australian contingent at the Commonwealth Air Forces Conference, where an RAAF presence was sought in the Middle East; this eventually resulted in [[No. 78 Wing RAAF|No. 78 Wing]] being re-formed and deployed to Malta in July 1952. Although Walters was keen to use the opportunity to acquire the RAAF's first [[North American F-86 Sabre]]s, political realities led him to negotiate a deal whereby the wing was equipped with leased British [[de Havilland Vampire|de Havilland Vampire FB.9s]].Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 202–203 In October 1952, Walters was promoted to acting [[air vice marshal]] and posted to Washington, D.C., to head up the Australian Joint Services Staff as successor to Air Vice Marshal Scherger.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49057535 |title=WA officer gets big defence job |newspaper=[[The West Australian]] |location=Perth |date=10 October 1952 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=13 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Walters' rank was made permanent in January 1954, when he succeeded Air Vice Marshal McCauley to become AOC [[RAAF Air Command|Home Command]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article29608773 |title=New RAAF commander arrives to-day |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|location=Sydney |date=6 January 1954 |accessdate=24 May 2013 |page=13 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Walters held this post, responsible for directing the RAAF's combat units, for three years. His tenure witnessed the introduction of the [[CAC Sabre]] to operational service with the Air Force, when No. 3 Squadron took delivery of its first machine in March 1956.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 75, 348–349 Walters was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] (CB) in the 1956 [[New Year Honours]].{{cite web|url=http://www.awm.gov.au/research/people/honours_and_awards/person.asp?p=357192|title= Awarded: Companion of the Bath|publisher= Australian War Memorial|accessdate= 12 March 2010}}{{LondonGazette|issue=40670|supp=yes|startpage=39|date=2 January 1956|accessdate=on 12 March 2010}} In March 1957, he was one of three candidates, along with Air Vice Marshals Scherger and Hancock, touted as possible successors to Air Marshal Sir John McCauley as Chief of the Air Staff (CAS), the RAAF's senior position. Though Walters was considered to be very able, Scherger had long been regarded as outstanding and was "easily the best material on offer" according to a former CAS, Air Marshal [[Donald Hardman|Sir Donald Hardman]].Stephens; Isaacs, ''High Fliers'', p. 123 Scherger gained the appointment, and Walters became Air Member for Personnel (AMP) on 21 October.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', pp. 499–500 As AMP he occupied a seat on the Air Board, the service's controlling body that comprised its senior officers and was chaired by the CAS.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 52 In this role Walters endorsed the recommendations of a review by the AOC Training Command, Air Vice Marshal [[Ian Dougald McLachlan|Ian McLachlan]], that led to a policy of [[RAAF College]] cadets undertaking academic degrees, in line with similar institutions in the other armed services; the college was subsequently renamed RAAF Academy.Frost, ''RAAF College & Academy'', pp. 36–38Stephens, ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 188–189 Walters served as AMP until August 1959. The following month he was appointed AOC [[RAAF Support Command|Support Command]], a new organisation created by merging the RAAF's former Training and Maintenance Commands.Stephens, ''Going Solo'', p. 76 When Scherger's term as CAS was due to complete in May 1961, Walters and Hancock were once more put forward to the [[Minister for Defence (Australia)|Minister for Air]] as potential replacements. "Walters was again unlucky", in the words of Air Force historians Alan Stephens and Keith Isaacs, Hancock's "professional ability, operational experience and personal qualities" being deemed more appropriate for the role.Stephens; Isaacs, ''High Fliers'', p. 137 ==Retirement== Walters left the RAAF on 16 May 1962, after completing his posting at Headquarters Support Command. His pending retirement and succession by Air Vice Marshal [[Douglas Candy]] had been announced the previous November.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article105853800 |title=RAAF changes |newspaper=The Canberra Times|location=Canberra |date=28 November 1961 |accessdate=22 May 2013 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Walters followed horse racing in private life. Survived by his wife and daughter, he died from [[Cardiorenal syndrome|cardiorenal failure]] in [[Heidelberg, Victoria|Heidelberg]], Melbourne, on 19 October 1968. He was accorded an Air Force funeral at The Scots Church, Melbourne, and cremated.{{cite news|title=Service funeral for AVM|work=RAAF News|date =December 1968|page= 3}} His pall bearers included two former CASs, Air Marshals Sir Richard Williams and [[George Jones (RAAF officer)|Sir George Jones]], along with Air Vice Marshals Henry Wrigley, [[Joe Hewitt (RAAF officer)|Joe Hewitt]], [[Colin Hannah]], and Douglas Candy. ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book|last=Alexander|first=Kristen|title=Clive Caldwell, Air Ace|publisher=[[Allen & Unwin]]|location=St. Leonards, New South Wales|year=2006|isbn=1-74114-705-0}} * {{cite book | year = 2000| title = How Not to Run an Air Force!
